Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Instruments for 3D Digital Mapping of Historic Structures and Archaeological Sites

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award permits Principal Investigator Dr. Beverly Chiarulli and Co-Principal Investigators, Drs. Scott Moore, Benjamin Ford, Sarah Neusius and Phillip Neusius to purchase a 3D Scanner system for digital documentation of the built environment and a Multiple Array Ground Penetrating Radar for below ground surveys of archaeological features. Individually, these instruments create high quality high resolution images of structures and landscapes as well as below ground archaeological features. Used together, they can create a digital library of above ground structures to provide a comparative database for the identification of below ground archaeological features. Because of this joint usage, they form an integrated system. The instruments will be employed by IUP faculty and students and our collaborators and their students from Howard University, the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, and the University of North Dakota.

Among the projects that will use the instruments are:
1. Dr. Chiarulli's project on historic cemeteries in western Pennsylvania will use 3D mapping of surface topography and standing gravestones in combination with the Multiple Array GPR to record forgotten grave sites;
2. Dr. Ford's investigation of shipwrecks in frozen lakes will use 3D imaging of surviving ships similar to wrecked vessels combined with winter surveys of Lake Ontario using the multiple antenna GPR to record otherwise potentially inaccessible shipwrecks for identification and protection;
3. Dr. Moore's survey of painted churches in the Troodos Mountains, Cyprus will aid in the preservation of the interior and exterior decoration of these churches by documenting the manner of construction of these buildings for an increased understanding of Byzantine Christianity and the development of rural religious practices;
4. Drs. Chiarulli and Neusius' investigation of Late Prehistoric Villages in western Pennsylvania will use the multiple array GPR for rapid below ground survey of large villages to discover faint prehistoric features and develop maps of village layouts without excavation;
5. Dr. Moore and his collaborators' will use 3D scanning to image above ground Roman ruins to understand site formation in Cyprus combined with a Multiple Array GPR survey of the entire coastal settlement for to the definition of the city's physical layout and provide the data to understand the development of this midsized Roman settlement and its role in local and regional trade; and
6. Drs. Neusius and Ford's Survey of Smicksburg, a 19th Century Commercial and Industrial Center in Indiana County, Pennsylvania will use 3D scanning to create a digital library of houses from this period and the multiple array GPR to produce detailed comparative subsurface information and record otherwise inaccessible heritage resources.

While the instruments provide rapid data collection, they also provide the capability to survey large landforms so investigations can move beyond the survey and analysis of single historic buildings or archaeological sites and conduct surveys of communities and landscapes. The impact of these instruments extends beyond their direct benefits to the initial projects. They will expand the investigator's ability to train IUP graduate and undergraduate students in critical and rapidly developing technologies as well as give students from three other universities opportunities to use the instruments. No less significant, the instrumentation would also ensure that the faculty participants themselves remain current in the use of advanced technology and will be able to incorporate it into their classes and other research projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding from this grant was for the acquisition of an IDS Stream X Multiple Array Ground Penetrating Radar unit and a Leica Scanstation C-10. The IDS Stream is a multiple array instrument in which the radar array is comprised of several antenna/receiver pairs. Multiple lines of data are acquired simultaneously as the array moves along the surface. As objects come into view, their shape, size and position can clearly be seen. The Leica Scanstation is an effective pulsed scanner, in a compact platform. This all-in-one scanner's capabilities give users the advantage of high-accuracy, long range scanning plus the advantage of fast, full dome interior scanning.

On of the primary objectives for this grant was to provide training to both graduate and undergraduate students. This equipment was introduced to students in an Archaeological Geophysics class. The Leica has been or is being used by two graduate students as part of their thesis project and one undergraduate student as part of her McNair Scholar Honors project. Jonathan Crise has used the scanner to record and identify an industrial complex in Fayette County, PA. Marion Smeltzer has completed on initial scan of remnant structures at the Allegheny Portage Railroad National Historic Park in Pennsylvania. Sarah LaFevre has completed an internal and external scan of the Altman Mill, a contributing element to the Saltsburg National Register Historic District in Pennsylvania. Students under the direction of Dr. R.Scott Moore completed scans of a Late Roman Basilica in Polis, Cyprus and an Archaic tomb in Atheinou, Cyprus. Jonathan Crise also completed a scan of an historic bridge as part of a pilot project with the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation to preserve architectural data and develop public programs. Two Geoscience students, Mike Barber and Drew Yetter under the direction of Dr. Nick Deardorff completed scans of the Mokst Butte lava flow in central Oregon. The IDS Stream will be used by graduate student David Breitkreutz under the direction of Dr. William Chadwick as part of his thesis integrating ground penetrating radar results with previously collected Leica Scanstation data.

A second objective was to disseminate information about the use and availability of the instruments. A workshop on the IDS Stream was presented at the National Park Service Archaeological Prospection Workshop, May 19-23, 2014. Approximately 40 attendees, representing federal and state agencies, Native American tribes, and universities were present at the workshop. A workshop on the Leica Scanstation was presented at the joint meeting of the National Alliance of Preservation Commissions and the Pennsylvania Statewide Conference on Heritage, July 16, 2014. The day long workshop introduced 21 participants to the basics of 3D laser scanning. A demonstration on the combined use of the IDS Stream and Leica Scanstation was presented at the 44th Annual Mid-Atlantic Archaeological Conference, March 14, 2014.

A blog was published on the use of the Leica for creating virtual worlds as venues for public archaeology. This was part of the Society for Historical Archaeology's week long series on Public Archaeology in January 2014.

A paper and poster were presented at the 79th Annual Meeting of the Society for American Archaeology in Austin, TX, April, 2014. A poster was presented at the 93rd Annual Meeting of the Transportation Research Board in Washington, D.C., January 13, 2014.

A third objective was to use the instruments in data collection, historic preservation and research activities. Additional completed data collection projects include: A Leica scan of Sutton Hall, a historic structure on the IUP campus; an IDS Stream survey of a parking lot on the IUP campus which is the site of a 19th to early 20th century glassworks; and an IDS Stream survey of the prehistoric site at Aztalan State Park in WIsconsin....
